ygData.subject: Re: Beginner's question: Stagnation
ygData.msgSnippet: Thanks Derek, First of all, I am using JNEAT from Ken s website, so there shouldn t be anything wrong in that direction. Second, yes, I think you are right,

Subject: Re: Beginner's question: Stagnation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=365384101; y=DPQcpPvyqF2dhXWcUizRysOBOoT-jq10ypHiLZNs4RicqtmEvsoVKzKRZOE

Thanks Derek,

First of all, I am using JNEAT from Ken's website, so there =
shouldn't 
be anything wrong in that direction.
Second, yes, I think you ar=
e right, there has to be some grand 
mistake I made but I can't find it. I =
have looked dozens of times 
over my code and still couldn't find the culpr=
it yet. But your 
answers are leading me on this search and are indeed very=
 helpful for 
me, so please stay tuned - even if this may seem to you very =
simple 
and boring ;-) I very much appreciate your help!
In order to answer=
 your questions: 

>"You say you've tried a simplified version of the task =
with a single 
joint, correct? So you have a network with 3 inputs (current=
 joint 
angle, goal joint angle, and current speed), and 1 output (a force =

applied to the joint?)."<
Yes, all of the above is absolutely correct. Mor=
e details: The 
simulator works with Radian angles [0; PI], these are then =
converted 
into degrees [0; 180] and given to NEAT (because it seemed easie=
r to 
calculate the error distance of the angles in degree than rad). 
Befo=
re being fed into the net, they are scaled down to [-1; 1]. Since 
the outp=
ut is (same as the hidden nodes) sigmoid between [0; 1], it 
is scaled up t=
o [-175; 175], which are the maximum boundaries of 
forces allowed in the s=
imulator. These forces are put into the 
simulator, it calculates the new p=
osition of the arm after applying 
the forces, momentum and gravitation. Af=
ter that, it starts all over 
again since this was only one of the 500 time=
steps of each sample.

>"The arm starts in one position and has to move the=
 joint into 
another position?"< 
Yes, that's correct.

>"If you have an ar=
m with just one joint and it has to move from one 
static position to anoth=
er, and you're explicitly giving the network 
the new position as input, th=
en yes, something is horribly wrong."<
Yes, it has to move from one static =
to another static position, the 
current position is given to the net at al=
l times and yes, there has 
to be something horribly wrong, but I don't kno=
w where to find my 
mistake. That's the problem with being new to a materia=
l, you don't 
know where exactly to start when something goes wrong, and th=
at's at 
the same time the reason why I'm so happy to have NEAT-experienced=
 
users like you showing me the right direction. 
Most of the last month I =
thought the culprit would be a wrong 
parameter setting, but as Colin point=
ed out, there seems to exist no 
"wrong" with parameters. The reason why I =
thought there could be 
wrong parameter settings was the fact that with ano=
ther fitness 
function and the hidden and output nodes being linear I got b=
etter 
results than now, but only with some specific parameter settings and=
 
not with others. (The fitness function was basically the same, but 
only =
calculating the mean difference of current and goal angles in 
the second h=
alf of time of each sample) But looking back, this was 
maybe just coincide=
nce and leading me into the wrong direction. 

I will start all over again =
today and look over my code from the 
beginning in order to find some error=
 I made. As soon as I find 
something suspect, I will post it here.
Thanks =
a lot for your help!

With best regards,
Matthias
